title-group.article-title: The Random-Threshold Generalized Unfolding Model and Its Application of Computerized Adaptive Testing

article-meta.aff: 1The Hong Kong Institute of Education, Tai Po, New Territories, Hong Kong

abstract.p: The random-threshold generalized unfolding model (RTGUM) was developed by treating the thresholds in the generalized unfolding model as random effects rather than fixed effects to account for the subjective nature of the selection of categories in Likert items. The parameters of the new model can be estimated with the JAGS (Just Another Gibbs Sampler) freeware, which adopts a Bayesian approach for estimation. A series of simulations was conducted to evaluate the parameter recovery of the new model and the consequences of ignoring the randomness in thresholds. The results showed that the parameters of RTGUM were recovered fairly well and that ignoring the randomness in thresholds led to biased estimates. Computerized adaptive testing was also implemented on RTGUM, where the Fisher information criterion was used for item selection and the maximum a posteriori method was used for ability estimation. The simulation study showed that the longer the test length, the smaller the randomness in thresholds, and the more categories in an item, the more precise the ability estimates would be.

In addition, ignoring the randomness in thresholds by fitting the rating scale model to data that were generated from the random-threshold rating scale model resulted in biased parameter estimates, overestimation of test reliability, and large infit and outfit item statistics for the thresholds. Test reliability was overestimated because the randomness in thresholds was mistakenly treated as a source of true variance in the rating scale model. In contrast, in the random-threshold rating scale model, the randomness in thresholds was partitioned out from θ, such that the resulting θ was purified and the estimation of test reliability was appropriate. As with rating scale items, Likert items (e.g., strongly disagree, disagree, agree, and strongly agree) are widely used in the human sciences. Unfolding IRT models have been fitted to Likert items. In the framework of unfolding models, when individuals are asked to express their level of agreement with an attitude statement, they tend to agree with the item to the extent that it is located close to their locations on a latent trait. A person disagrees with an item for one of two reasons: Either the item is located far below or far above the person’s location. Hence, there are two possible latent responses—“disagree from below” and “disagree from above”—associated with the single observed response of “disagree.” The two latent responses are often assumed to follow a standard IRT model. Given the great similarity in the selection of categories between rating scale items and Likert items, the same subjective randomness in thresholds of rating scale items may apply to Likert items. It would thus be of great value to develop a random-threshold unfolding IRT model to account for such subjective randomness in thresholds, which is the first purpose of this study. To further increase the applicability of the new model, computerized adaptive testing (CAT) should be developed, which is the second purpose of this study. In the following, the new model is introduced, and the parameter estimation procedures and computer software are outlined. A series of simulations is conducted to evaluate parameter recovery, and the results are summarized. CAT algorithms are developed using the new model, a series of simulations is conducted to evaluate the CAT algorithms, and the results are summarized. Finally, conclusions are drawn, and suggestions for future studies are provided.

sec.title: Parameter Estimation
sec.p: RTGUM can be high dimensional. Marginal maximum likelihood estimation methods, although widely used in unidimensional IRT models, become less efficient in high-dimensional IRT models because of the complexity in integrating multiple dimensions, computing second derivatives, and inversing matrices. The Bayesian approach with Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods is an alternative and has been adopted to estimate the parameters in unfolding IRT models (de la Torre, Stark, & Chernyshenko, 2006; Roberts & Thompson, 2011) and multidimensional IRT models (Béguin & Glas, 2001; Sheng & Wikle, 2008). This approach is adopted for RTGUM in this study. In the Bayesian estimation, specifications of a statistical model, prior distributions of model parameters, and observed data are required to produce a joint posterior distribution for the model parameters. MCMC methods provide an alternative and simple way to simulate the joint posterior distribution of the unknown quantities and obtain simulation-based estimates of posterior parameters of interest. The Metropolis–Hastings (Chib & Greenberg, 1995) and the Gibbs sampling algorithms (Robert & Casella, 2004) are two major procedures to construct the Markov chain through transition density to target density. A procedure modified from the Metropolis–Hastings algorithms and Metropolis-within-Gibbs algorithm offers much potential for effective estimation of complicated statistical models. The procedure is implemented in the WinBUGS (Lunn, Thomas, Best, & Spiegelhalter, 2000) or JAGS (Just Another Gibbs Sampler) program (Plummer, 2003), in which a multiple-block approach is used and the proposal density is characteristically symmetric. At each block for each parameter, whether the drawing parameters (a candidate state) will be updated at the next chain depends on the probability of move, which is the ratio of the posterior density under the candidate state to that under the current state. If the ratio is higher, the candidate state will have a higher probability of being the next stage of the chain; otherwise, with the lower ratio, the previous state will be retained (Bolt & Lall, 2003).

In this study of parameter estimation in RTGUM using WinBUGS, unexpected abortion was encountered during sampling, and vague error messages were reported. This might be because exp(γ) fluctuated significantly during sampling. To resolve this problem, JAGS (Version 3.2), which has been adopted in recent IRT studies (Curtis, 2010), was adopted because of its stable estimation for RTGUM. In addition, it converged faster than WinBUGS and did not abort during sampling.

sec.title: Simulation Study 1: Parameter Recovery of GUM and RTGUM
Design
sec.p: Four major conditions were manipulated. In Condition 1, GUM was fitted to data simulated from the same GUM. In Condition 2, RTGUM was fitted to data simulated from the same RTGUM. In Condition 3, RTGUM was fitted to data simulated from GUM. In Condition 4, GUM was fitted to data simulated from RTGUM. Conditions 1 and 2 were used to evaluate parameter recovery when the simulated data were analyzed with the true (data-generating) model. It was expected that the parameter recovery would be satisfactory. Condition 3 was used to evaluate the consequences of using an unnecessarily complicated model (i.e., RTGUM) to analyze data without randomness in thresholds (i.e., data simulated from GUM). It was expected that the estimates for the γ variances would be close to zero and that the estimates for the other parameters would be close to their true values. In other words, it would do little harm to fit RTGUM to data without randomness in thresholds. Condition 4 was used to evaluate the consequences of ignoring randomness in thresholds by fitting GUM to data that were simulated from RTGUM. It was expected that the parameter estimation would be very poor.

The test consisted of 10 four-point Likert items and a sample size of 1,500. The α parameters ranged from 0.76 to 1.34. The δ parameters ranged uniformly between −2 and 2. For each item,

A MATLAB computer program was written to generate data. Thirty replications were made under each condition, mainly because each replication could take dozens of hours of computational time. In the authors’ experience, 30 replications appeared to be sufficient to gain reliable inferences, because the sampling variation appeared to be rather small. Other studies that used Bayesian estimation for complicated IRT models often had 10 replications or fewer (Bolt & Lall, 2003; Klein Entink, Fox, & van der Linden, 2009; Li, Bolt, & Fu, 2006; van der Linden, Klein Entink, & Fox, 2010).

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p: JAGS was used to analyze the simulated data. The priors were set as follows: δ ~ N(0, 102); α ~ logN(1, 1); τ1 ~ logN(1, 1); τ2 ~ logN(1, 1); τ3 ~ logN(1, 1); θ and γs ~ N(0, σ2), and σ2 had a uniform prior ranging from 0 to 4. The best sampling method was chosen automatically by the JAGS compiler. There were 2,000 iterations as burn-in, followed by an additional 8,000 iterations. When thinned by 4, the final available sample size was 2,000. The mean of the final samples was the expected a posteriori (EAP) estimate, and the standard deviation (SD) of the final samples was the standard error of parameter estimates. The JAGS code for the RTGUM with four-point Likert items is listed in the Appendix.

sec.title: Condition 1: GUM fit to GUM data
sec.p: The parameters were recovered fairly well. The bias values were between −0.032 and 0.050, and the RMSE values were between 0.010 and 0.089 (M = 0.057). The magnitudes of the bias and RMSE were similar to those found in the IRT literature (de la Torre et al., 2006; Roberts, Donoghue, & Laughlin, 2002; Roberts & Thompson, 2011).

sec.title: Condition 2: RTGUM fit to RTGUM data
sec.p: Again, the parameters were recovered fairly well. The bias values were between −0.025 and 0.037, and the RMSE values were between 0.035 and 0.107 (M = 0.056). The variances of γ1, γ2, and γ3 were recovered well, with RMSE between 0.036 and 0.062.

sec.title: Condition 3: RTGUM fit to GUM data
sec.p: The parameters were recovered as well as those under Condition 2. The bias values were between −0.061 and 0.111, and the RMSE values were between 0.020 and 0.120 (M = 0.059). The zero variance of the three γs had biased values of 0.018, 0.036, and 0.111 for γ1, γ2, and γ3, respectively. The RMSE values were 0.020, 0.038, and 0.120 for γ1, γ2, and γ3, respectively. As shown in the left panel of Table 2, the RE values were between 0.64 and 3.77 (M = 1.15), suggesting that, in general, it did little harm to fit RTGUM to GUM data, as compared with when the data-generating GUM was fit.

sec.title: Condition 4: GUM fit to RTGUM data
sec.p: The bias values of the parameter estimates were much worse than those under the other three conditions. The bias values were between −0.225 and 0.131, and the RMSE values were between 0.032 and 0.249 (M = 0.092). As shown in the right panel of Table 2, the RE values were between 0.53 and 7.98 (M = 2.86), suggesting that ignoring the randomness in thresholds by fitting GUM to RTGUM data yielded very poor parameter estimation, as compared with when the data-generating RTGUM was fit.

sec.title: Real-Data Analysis
sec.p:
The data set, downloaded from www.psychology.gatech.edu/unfolding/data.html, consisted of 20 six-point items (strongly disagree, disagree, slightly disagree, slightly agree, agree, and strongly agree) about censorship and 223 respondents (Roberts, 1995). Three models (RTGUM, GUM, and GGUM) were fit to the censorship data using JAGS. The same constraints for model identification in the simulations were imposed. There were 4,000 iterations as burn-in, followed by 16,000 iterations. A total of 4,000 MCMC samples were obtained with a thinning factor of 4 on the 16,000 iterations for parameter estimation. The deviance information criterion (DIC) was computed for model comparison. The smaller the DIC, the more favorable the model would be. To derive the test reliability, the authors first computed the Pearson correlation of θ estimates between every pair of the 4,000 MCMC samples, resulting in a total of
C

correlations. The mean of these correlations was the estimate for the test reliability, and the SD of these correlations was the standard error.

The DIC was 12,399 for RTGUM, 13,486 for GUM, and 13,232 for GGUM, suggesting RTGUM had a better fit than the other two models. Under RTGUM, the estimated variance (and its standard error) for the five random thresholds was 0.149 (0.048), 0.057 (0.020), 0.010 (0.005), 0.102 (0.038), and 0.229 (0.082), respectively. The variances for the middle thresholds (i.e., the second, third, and fourth thresholds) were smaller than those for the first and last thresholds, which was consistent with those found in rating scale items (W.-C. Wang et al., 2006; W.-C. Wang & Wu, 2011). The test reliability was .85 for RTGUM, .89 for GUM, and .89 for GGUM. As found in the literature on rating scale items (W.-C. Wang et al., 2006; W.-C. Wang & Wu, 2011), ignoring the randomness in thresholds yielded an overestimation of test reliability.

sec.p: Examinees were generated from two conditions: fixed value and normal distribution. In the fixed-value condition, θ = −3, −2, −1, 0, 1, 2, and 3, each level with 1,000 examinees (replications). The γ values for these 1,000 examinees at each θ level were generated according to the above σγ specification. This condition enabled the assessment of the bias and RMSE for person parameter estimates at each θ level. In the normal-distribution condition, a total of 10,000 examinees were simulated from the multivariate normal distribution with mean vector of zero, unit variance for θ, variances for γs specified previously, and zero covariances between θ and γs, as specified in RTGUM. This condition allowed the assessment of the overall effect of CAT algorithms across person distributions.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Figure 6 shows the bias and RMSE in θ estimates for six-point items under the fixed-value condition. The bias approached zero for every θ level in all three σγ conditions as the CAT program proceeded to its maximum length of 100 items. When the test length was not long (e.g., fewer than 10 items), negative θ values were overestimated and positive θ values were underestimated (i.e., scale shrunk toward the prior mean of zero). To reduce the scale shrinkage, a long test would be required when σγ was large, especially for extreme θ values of −3 and 3. In other words, the larger the value of σγ, the longer the test required to reduce the bias for extreme θ values. Like the bias, the longer the test and the smaller the value of σγ, the smaller RMSE would be.

sec.p: Figure 7 presents the bias and RMSE in ability estimates for two-point items under the fixed-value condition. Those for four-point items are not presented due to space constraints, but they can be inferred from Figures 6 and 7. The major findings for the six-point items were obtained for the two-point items. The bias approached zero as the CAT program proceeded. The θ estimates shrank toward the prior mean, and the shrinkage was more serious for extreme θ values. A longer test length and a smaller σγ led to a smaller RMSE. During early stages of the CAT (e.g., the first 20 items), there was significant fluctuation in the bias and RMSE, because the estimation of extreme θ values was not stable and multiple maxima of the likelihood were easily encountered. A comparison of Figures 6 and 7 revealed that the more categories each item had, the better the θ estimation.

sec.p: The MD and RMSD of the 10,000 examinees generated from a normal distribution are reported in Figure 8. As the CAT program proceeded, MD approached zero and RMSD became smaller. Furthermore, the smaller the value of σγ, the smaller the RMSD would be. The MD had a large fluctuation, and the RMSD was large during early stages because of multiple maxima in the likelihood. A comparison of two-point (Figures 8a and 8b), four-point (Figures 8c and 8d), and six-point items (Figures 8e and 8f) revealed that the more categories each item had, the closer MD would be to zero and the smaller RMSD would be.

sec.title: Conclusion and Discussion
sec.p: When responding to rating scale items or Likert items, respondents are asked to select a category that best describes themselves. It is likely that different persons hold different perspectives on the categories and the thresholds between categories. To describe the variation in the selection of categories across persons, the authors developed RTGUM by adding a set of random-effect parameters to GUM so that the thresholds became random across persons. The γ variance depicts the magnitude of variation in subjective judgment of the thresholds. The smaller the γ variance, the smaller the variation in the subjective judgment. RTGUM comprises GUM as a special case in which the γ variances for thresholds are all zero. The parameters of RTGUM can be estimated using JAGS, which uses MCMC methods. It takes dozens of hours in current personal computers for one replication in the simulation study. The computation time should be feasible for empirical data analysis.

Several conclusions can be drawn from the simulation study of parameter recovery. First, the parameters of RTGUM and GUM can be recovered fairly well. Second, when RTGUM is fit to GUM data, the parameter estimation is satisfactory, and the estimates for the γ variances are very close to zero, suggesting it does little harm to fit RTGUM to GUM data. Third, ignoring the randomness in thresholds by fitting GUM to RTGUM data yields poor parameter estimates.

In addition to the development of RTGUM, the authors implemented CAT algorithms to facilitate its application. The FI method and the MAP method were adopted for item selection and ability estimation. The simulations showed that the longer the test length, the smaller the γ variance, and the more categories each item had, the better the θ estimation. In addition, the MAP method, as a Bayesian estimation method, yielded shrunken estimates toward the prior mean. This shrinkage was serious when the γ variance was large for extreme θ values. As the test length was increased, the shrinkage decreased.

The following issues can be investigated in the future: First, the applicability of RTGUM to real data should be further explored. Second, this study demonstrates the CAT application of RTGUM under a limited situation. Many methods of item selection, ability estimation, practical constraints of item exposure control and content balancing, and stopping rules (e.g., fixed precision or fixed length) could be further investigated. The fluctuation in ability estimation during the early stages of CAT deserves further investigation. Other item-selection methods, such as those based on the Kullback–Leibler information and mutual information, may help in selecting more appropriate candidate items and reducing the fluctuation (Mulder & Linden, 2010). Third, computerized classification testing (where persons are classified into a few categories rather than given point ability estimates), test linking, and differential item functioning are important applications of IRT models that could be reinvestigated using RTGUM. Fourth, RTGUM involves a single latent trait θ and a single level of data structure. The single latent trait can be generalized to a vector (e.g., multiple tests of Likert items), and the single level can be generalized to multiple levels (e.g., students sampled from different schools). Thus, a multidimensional and multilevel version of RTGUM could be developed.
